name: Victoria Falls
description: One of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World, Victoria Falls, or 'Mosi-oa-Tunya' (The Smoke That Thunders), is a breathtaking waterfall on the Zambezi River. Visitors can enjoy bungee jumping, helicopter flights, and sunset cruises.

name: Hwange National Park
description: Zimbabwe’s largest national park, covering over 14,600 sq km, home to large herds of elephants, lions, zebras, and more than 400 bird species. Perfect for game drives and walking safaris.

name: Matobo National Park
description: Famous for dramatic balancing rock formations, Bushmen rock art, and one of Africa’s largest leopard populations. The park is also home to white rhinos and the grave of Cecil Rhodes.

name: Great Zimbabwe Ruins
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, these ruins are the remains of an ancient Shona city built between the 11th and 15th centuries, featuring impressive stone structures and historical significance.

name: Mana Pools National Park
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, this park along the Zambezi River is known for its abundant wildlife, including elephants, lions, hippos, and crocodiles. It offers exceptional canoe and walking safaris.

name: Chinhoyi Caves
description: A mystical limestone cave system featuring the stunning Sleeping Pool with deep blue waters. It is a popular site for scuba diving and holds historical significance in local mythology.

name: Nyanga National Park
description: Home to Mount Nyangani (Zimbabwe’s highest peak) and Mutarazi Falls. The park is great for hiking, fishing, and exploring ancient ruins while spotting unique wildlife.

name: Gonarezhou National Park
description: Meaning 'Place of Elephants,' this remote park is known for the stunning red sandstone Chilojo Cliffs and diverse wildlife, including elephants, lions, and wild dogs.
